title: Agile
body: The best way to manage a reproducible analytical pipeline is by taking an Agile approach. In practice, this means prioritising user needs, working software and empowered teams.

title: New Block Title
body: Whilst the techniques and products vary, the process of creating an analytical product can usually be generalised to

title: Quality assurance
body: Each stage of an analytical pipeline should be underpinned by a quality assurance (QA) process. This is to ensure it has been accurately performed. Traditionally, the QA process involves an independent person checking or recreating each stage of the pipeline. This sort of repetitive checking is difficult for humans and is very time consuming. Even the most diligent analyst will get fatigued and distracted when checking a spreadsheet cell by cell. Research on spreadsheet error found that 94% of spreadsheets contained errors and average error detection rates are only 60%.

title: New Block Title
body:
Reproducibility is our first pillar of good analysis. We cannot guarantee that our research will always be accurate or fit for purpose. However, we can ensure that if someone else runs the same analysis with the same data, they will get the same results.

Guaranteeing reproducibility relies on transparent production processes. Processes should be open and effectively documented. The successful running of a pipeline must not depend on the unwritten knowledge of individual analysts. Good documentation should also show how our methods map to our implementation. When reproducibility is guaranteed, users and colleagues can focus on other quality checks. For example, they can verify that the implementation is correct and that the research meets the user needs.

title: New Block Title
body: Using a programming language such as R or Python allows us to automate the manual steps in our pipelines. We can dramatically reduce the need to move data between different software environments. Instead, we can import the data once and then run all our cleaning, processing, and analysis from a single script. We can remove copy-paste steps by generating our data visualisations and reports in the same place that we do our analysis. Using tools like R Markdown and Jupyter Notebooks, we can directly generate webpages, PDFs and presentation slides at the same time as running our analysis.

title: Example - Nature of Crime RAP
body:
In March 2020, the Centre for Crime and Justice, based at the Office for National Statistics, started a project to automate the production of their Nature of Crime tables. The 100+ tables were previously created using Excel and SPSS, by a team of thirteen analysts.

The team worked with their RAP Champions to transform the way these tables were produced. They created pipelines using R and python and adopted Git for version control. They wrote functions with unit tests and brought them together into two packages. The team collaborated using an internal GitLab repository. When they published their tables on gov.uk, they also published their code openly on GitHub.

Using their new pipelines, the team can produce their outputs in under an hour – a saving of 1,500 person hours. When they needed to produce new analysis, they were able to add nine new tables to the pipeline in just an hour. With the time saved, the team have been able to publish more granular analysis for their users. They have also adapted their code to produce other statistics.

In the following video, the team discuss the benefits RAP has brought them.
